question_feedback.student_choice: BGP maintains the complete AS path to prevent loops and enable policy-based routing decisions
question_feedback.correct_answer: BGP maintains the complete AS path to prevent loops and enable policy-based routing decisions
question_feedback.explanation: BGP is a path-vector protocol because it maintains the complete path of autonomous systems (AS_PATH) that a route has traversed. This allows for loop prevention and enables complex policy decisions based on which ASes are in the path, unlike simple distance-vector protocols that only consider hop count.

question_feedback.student_choice: To prevent route hijacking by accepting only legitimate prefixes from customers and peers
question_feedback.correct_answer: To prevent route hijacking by accepting only legitimate prefixes from customers and peers
question_feedback.explanation: Route filtering is primarily used as a security measure to prevent route hijacking attacks. ISPs implement prefix filters to ensure they only accept route announcements for IP prefixes that their customers or peers are authorized to advertise, preventing malicious actors from redirecting traffic.

question_feedback.student_choice: Local preference allows administrators to implement business policies that override shortest-path routing
question_feedback.correct_answer: Local preference allows administrators to implement business policies that override shortest-path routing
question_feedback.explanation: BGP prioritizes local preference over AS path length because it allows network administrators to implement business and policy decisions that may override pure shortest-path routing. This enables ISPs to prefer certain transit providers, implement traffic engineering, or route traffic based on commercial agreements rather than just path length.

question_feedback.student_choice: BGP supports policy-based routing between different administrative domains with potentially conflicting interests
question_feedback.correct_answer: BGP supports policy-based routing between different administrative domains with potentially conflicting interests
question_feedback.explanation: BGP was designed to handle inter-domain routing between autonomous systems that may have different administrative policies, business relationships, and trust levels. IGPs like OSPF assume a single administrative domain with common goals, while BGP enables policy-based routing decisions between organizations that may have competing interests.

question_feedback.student_choice: Unstable physical links or routing loops; implement route dampening
question_feedback.correct_answer: Unstable physical links or routing loops; implement route dampening
question_feedback.explanation: Route flapping typically occurs when routes are repeatedly withdrawn and re-announced due to unstable links or configuration issues. Route dampening is the appropriate BGP feature that suppresses unstable routes by penalizing frequently changing prefixes, preventing them from destabilizing the global routing table.
